title: E field - spheres with charge inside or at surface

content.question: Two solid spheres, Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, both have the same radius, as shown in the figure. The spheres are far apart from each other and both are in electrostatic equilibrium. In Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, there is a net charge everywhere within the sphere’s volume: a charge <math alttext="positive Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>+</mo><mi>Q</mi></math> uniformly distributed throughout the top half of the sphere, and a charge <math alttext="negative Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mi>Q</mi></mpadded></math> uniformly distributed throughout the bottom half of the sphere. In Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, there is a net charge over the entire surface but not inside the sphere: a charge <math alttext="positive Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mi>Q</mi></mpadded></math> uniformly distributed over the top half of the sphere’s surface, and a charge <math alttext="negative Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mi>Q</mi></mpadded></math> uniformly distributed over the bottom half of the sphere’s surface. As indicated in the figure, there is a downward electric field in each sphere at a point located in the top half of the sphere. Which of the following correctly describes whether each sphere is a conductor or an insulator?

choices.label: Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is a conductor and Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is an insulator.
Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is an insulator and Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is a conductor.
